conclusion: The centres of the three circular sections are O1 (top log A), O2 (left log B) and O3 (right log C).
A touches B and C, so O1O2 = O1O3 = 2R.
Triangle O1O2O3 is isosceles with sides O1O2 = O1O3 = 2R and base O2O3 = 2R·√3 (by the law of cosines).

premise: Place O2 at (–√3 R, 0), O3 at ( √3 R, 0). From O1O2 = 2R
The line O2O1 (and O3O1) therefore makes an angle tan θ = (R)/(√3 R)

conclusion: For log A there are only three forces: its weight, mg, downward; normal reaction N from B, acting along O2O1 (30° above the horizontal, toward O1); normal reaction N from C, acting symmetrically along O3O1.

premise: Vertical equilibrium of A: the vertical components of the two normals must balance its weight

conclusion: For log B the forces are weight mg downward; ground normal N_g upward; ground friction f horizontal (acting outward, i.e. to the left, because the contact with A pushes B inward); normal from A (same magnitude N found above) acting along O2O1, i.e. 30° up from the horizontal, pointing toward O1 (to the right and up).

premise: Resolve N into components: Horizontal N_h = N cos 30°
Resolve N into components: Vertical N_v = N sin 30°
Horizontal equilibrium of B: N_h – f = 0
Vertical equilibrium of B: N_g + N_v – mg = 0

conclusion: The problem states that the logs on the ground are just about to slide and that the maximum static friction equals the kinetic (sliding) friction.
μ is the (dynamic) coefficient of friction ground–log that we must find.
